author: Amy Remeikis and David Rowe
title: Entire NSW RSL Council stands down as financial scandal continues
text:
Entire NSW RSL Council stands down as financial scandal continues Amy Remeikis and David Rowe twitter TWEET More 
The NSW council of the RSL has agreed to step aside amid mounting pressure from the rank-and-file as well as the league's national board over the financial scandals plaguing the state leadership. 
After resisting pressure for weeks, the NSW council's remaining members – seven had already quit – have stepped aside and are expected to be replaced by one or more administrators while investigations into the financial questions continue. SHARE The NSW RSL is under scrutiny over the state of its finances. Photo: Getty Images 
The decision by the council to fall on its sword follows months of reporting by Fairfax Media about serious financial issues that are now being probed by several different investigations. 
Former NSW president Don Rowe spent $475,000 on his corporate credit card over six years, including $213,000 in cash and payment of five mobile phone accounts for family members. Related Content RSL NSW council prepared to stand aside over financial scandal 
He was allowed to resign quietly while citing health reasons. Even after the council was advised by an auditor that there was a "prima facie case of fraud" no further action was taken and the RSL membership was not informed of the concerns. 
Eight past and present state councillors including Mr Rowe and Rod White - who went on to become national president – received shares of $2.5 million in consulting fees from the league's aged care arm, RSL LifeCare. Advertisement 
NSW Veterans Affairs Minister David Elliott has referred Mr Rowe's credit card use to police and asked Fair Trading Minister Victor Dominello to investigate the LifeCare payments. The Australian Charities and Not-for-Profits Commission is also investigating and there are several internal audits being carried out. 
A spokeswoman for the national league confirmed the NSW council had stepped aside on Friday afternoon, but gave no further details. 
It is understood RSL members are still in the process of being told of the move. 
NSW president John Haines had been contacted for comment. 
with Heath Aston
